revision.text:
{{redirect|MiG}} {{other uses}} {{Infobox company |name = Russian Aircraft Corporation MiG |former_name = {{unbulleted list|OKB-155|Mikoyan and Gurevich Design Bureau}} |logo = [[Image:MiG logo web.png|The MiG logo]] |type = [[Division (business)|Division]] |foundation = [[Moscow]], Russia ({{start date|1939|12|8}}) |location = |parent = [[United Aircraft Corporation]] |founder = {{unbulleted list|[[Artem Mikoyan]]|[[Mikhail Gurevich (aircraft designer)|Mikhail Gurevich]]}} |num_employees = |industry = [[Aerospace]] and [[Arms industry|defense]] |products = {{unbulleted list|Military aircraft|Civil airliners}} |revenue = |homepage = {{URL|www.migavia.ru/}} }}
'''Russian Aircraft Corporation MiG''' (Российская самолетостроительная корпорация «МиГ»), or '''RSK MiG''', is a [[Russian aerospace]] [[joint stock company]]. Formerly '''Mikoyan-and-Gurevich Design Bureau''' ({{lang-ru|Микоян и Гуревич, МиГ}}), then simply '''Mikoyan''', it is a [[military aircraft]] [[OKB|design bureau]], primarily designing [[fighter aircraft]]. Its [[head office]] is in [[Begovoy District]], [[Northern Administrative Okrug]], [[Moscow]].<ref>"[http://www.migavia.ru/eng/contacts/ Contacts]." Mikoyan. Retrieved on 30 August 2011. "Russian Aircraft Corporation "MiG" 125284, Russian Federation, Moscow, 1-st Botkinsky drive, 7" – [http://www.migavia.ru/contacts/ Address in Russian]: "125284, Российская Федерация, Москва, 1-й Боткинский проезд, д.7"</ref>
It was formerly a [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] design bureau, and was founded by [[Artem Mikoyan]] and [[Mikhail Gurevich (aircraft designer)|Mikhail Gurevich]] as "Mikoyan and Gurevich", with the bureau prefix "'''MiG'''." Upon Gurevich's death in 1976, Gurevich's name was dropped from the name of the bureau, although the bureau prefix remained "MiG". The firm also operates several machine-building and design bureaus, including the [[Kamov]] helicopter plant.
MiG aircraft are a staple of the Soviet and [[Russian air force]]s, and the Soviet Union sold many of these aircraft within [[Soviet sphere of influence|its sphere of influence]]. They have been used by the militaries of [[China]], [[North Korea]], and [[North Vietnam]] in aerial confrontations with American and allied forces, and form part of the air forces of many [[Arab]] nations.
In 2006, the Russian government merged 100% of Mikoyan shares with [[Ilyushin]], [[Irkut (aircraft manufacturer)|Irkut]], [[Sukhoi]], [[Tupolev]], and [[Yakovlev]] as a new company named [[United Aircraft Corporation]].<ref name="nyt_united_aircraft">"[http://www.nytimes.com/2006/02/22/business/worldbusiness/22air.html?_r=1&oref=login Russian Aircraft Industry Seeks Revival Through Merger]." ''[[The New York Times]].'' February 22, 2006.</ref> Specifically, Mikoyan and Sukhoi were placed within the same operating unit.<ref>[http://www.aviationweek.com/aw/blogs/defense/index.jsp?plckController=Blog&plckBlogPage=BlogViewPost&newspaperUserId=27ec4a53-dcc8-42d0-bd3a-01329aef79a7&plckPostId=Blog:27ec4a53-dcc8-42d0-bd3a-01329aef79a7Post:8c2173f8-2f61-473b-bca3-e668f48ddf44&plckScript=blogScript&plckElementId=blogDest Aviationweek.com]</ref>
==List of MiG aircraft== [[Image:MiG-15 RB1.jpg|thumb|[[MiG-15]]]] [[Image:1 Pucki Dywizjon Lotniczy MiG-21 bis.jpg|thumb|[[MiG-21]]]] [[Image:Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-23MLD Flogger K USAF.jpg|thumb|[[MiG-23]]]] [[Image:MiG-25 fig2agrau USAF.jpg|thumb|[[MiG-25]]]] [[Image:Soviet MiG-29 DF-ST-99-04977.JPG|thumb|[[MiG-29]]]] [[Image:Mig29M-OVT.jpg|thumb|MiG-29OVT]] [[Image:Russian Air Force MiG-31 inflight Pichugin.jpg|thumb|[[Mig-31|MiG-31B]]]] [[Image:Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-35 MAKS'2007 Pichugin.jpg|thumb|[[MiG-35]]]]
===Production=== * [[Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-1|MiG-1]], 1940 * [[Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-3|MiG-3]], 1941 * [[Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-9|MiG-9]], 1946 * [[Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-15|MiG-15]], 1948 * [[Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-17|MiG-17]], 1953 * [[Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-19|MiG-19]], 1954, MiG's first supersonic fighter. * [[Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-21|MiG-21]], 1956, [[Multirole combat aircraft|multirole fighter]] that would be widely exported and become the backbone of dozens of air forces. The [[Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-21|MiG-21]] is the highest selling jet fighter in world history. ** [[Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-21 variants]] * [[Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-23|MiG-23]], 1967 (third use of MiG-23 designation) * [[Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-25|MiG-25]], 1965, interceptor fighter and recce/strike aircraft. * [[Mikoyan MiG-27|MiG-27]], 1970, a ground-attack aircraft derived from the [[Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-23|MiG-23]]. * [[Mikoyan MiG-29|MiG-29]], 1977, a [[Fourth generation fighter|4th generation]] multirole/air superiority fighter comparable to earlier and mid-life iterations of the American [[McDonnell Douglas F/A-18 Hornet]], [[General Dynamics F-16 Fighting Falcon]], and the French [[Dassault Mirage 2000]]. ** [[Mikoyan MiG-29M|MiG-29M]], improved variant, 4+ generation multirole/air superiority fighter comparable to the Chinese [[Chengdu J-10]], later iterations of the American [[McDonnell Douglas F/A-18 Hornet]] and [[General Dynamics F-16 Fighting Falcon]], as well as the Japanese-American [[Mitsubishi F-2]]. *** [[Mikoyan MiG-29K|MiG-29K]], 1988, 4+ generation multirole/air superiority fighter and the naval variant of the [[Mikoyan MiG-29M|MiG-29M]]. Modern [[Mikoyan MiG-29K|MiG-29Ks]] compete directly with [[Boeing F/A-18E/F Super Hornet]]. It also competes more indirectly with naval variants of the [[Chengdu J-10]] and French [[Dassault Rafale]]. * [[Mikoyan MiG-31|MiG-31]], 1975, [[Fourth generation fighter|4th generation]] [[interceptor aircraft|interceptor]]. * [[Mikoyan MiG-35|MiG-35]], 2007, multi-role 4++ generation jet fighter (based on the MiG-29M), comparable to the American [[Boeing F/A-18E/F Super Hornet]], European [[Eurofighter Typhoon]], and [[Dassault Rafale]].
===Experimental=== * [[Mikoyan-Gurevich DIS|DIS/MiG-5]], 1941 (escort fighter) * [[Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-6|MiG-6]], 1940 (reconnaissance/ground attack aircraft) * [[Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-3#Variants|MiG-7]], 1944 * [[Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-8|MiG-8]] ''Utka'', 1945 * [[Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-1|MiG I-200]], 1939, prototype for MiG-1 **[[Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-1|MiG IP-201]], 1941, MiG-1 modified into a testbed for an experimental machine gun * [[Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-3|MiG I-210/MiG-9]], 1941, MiG-3 modified with a Shvetsov M-82 radial engine * [[Mikoyan-Gurevich I-211|MiG I-211/MiG-9E]], 1942, prototype high-altitude fighter developed from the I-210 * [[Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-3|MiG I-220/MiG-11]], 1943 * [[Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-3|MiG I-221]], 1943, high-altitude interceptor based on I-210 * [[Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-3|MiG I-222]], 1944, I-221 modified with a pressurized cockpit * [[Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-3|MiG I-224]], 1944 * [[Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-3|MiG I-225]], 1944 * [[Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-3|MiG I-230/MiG-3U]], 1942, improved MiG-3 * [[Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-3|MiG I-231]], 1943 * [[Mikoyan-Gurevich I-250|MiG I-250 (N)]], 1945 (aka "MiG-13"), motorjet fighter prototype * [[Mikoyan-Gurevich I-270|MiG I-270 (Zh)]], 1947 * [[Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-9|MiG I-300]], 1945, prototype for MiG-9 * [[Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-9|MiG I-301T/MiG-9UTI]], 1947, prototype trainer version of MiG-9 * [[Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-9|MiG I-302]], 1947, MiG-9 with relocated cannon * [[Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-9|MiG I-305]], 1947, MiG-9 with a single Lyulka TR-1 engine * [[Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-9|MiG I-307]], 1947, MiG-9 with RD-20F or RD-21 engines * [[Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-15|MiG I-310]], 1947, prototype for MiG-15 * [[Mikoyan-Gurevich I-320|MiG I-320 (R)]], 1949 * [[Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-17|MiG I-340]], 1952, MiG-17 with Lyulka AM-5F engines * [[Mikoyan-Gurevich I-350|MiG I-350 (M)]], 1951 * [[Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-19|MiG I-360]], 1952, precursor of MiG-19 * [[Mikoyan-Gurevich I-370|MiG I-370/I-1]], 1955 * [[Mikoyan-Gurevich I-3|MiG I-380/I-3]], 1953 * [[Mikoyan-Gurevich I-3|MiG I-410/I-3P]], 1954 * [[Mikoyan-Gurevich I-3|MiG I-420/I-3U]], 1956 * [[Mikoyan-Gurevich I-7|MiG I-7U]], 1957, heavy interceptor fighter * [[Mikoyan-Gurevich I-75|MiG I-75]], 1958, swept-wing interceptor developed from the I-3 * [[Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-19|MiG SM-12]], 1957, developed into the MiG-21 * [[Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-17|MiG SN]], 1953 * [[Mikoyan-Gurevich Ye-2|Ye-2]], 1955 * [[List of Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-21 variants|Ye-4/Ye-5]], 1955 * [[Mikoyan-Gurevich Ye-8|Ye-8]], 1962, experimental fighter aircraft * [[List of Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-21 variants#Ye-50|Ye-50]], 1956 * [[Mikoyan-Gurevich Ye-150 family|Ye-150]], 1958 * [[Mikoyan-Gurevich Ye-150 family|Ye-151]], cannon armed version of Ye-150 * [[Mikoyan-Gurevich Ye-150 family|Ye-152]], 1959, fighter * [[Mikoyan-Gurevich Ye-150 family|Ye-166]], fictitious designation of Ye-152-1 * MiG-23 – (first use of designation) production designation of [[Mikoyan-Gurevich Ye-2A]], 1956 * MiG-23 – (second use of designation) early name of [[Mikoyan-Gurevich Ye-8]] (E-8/1 and E-8/2), 1960 * [[Mikoyan MiG-AT|MiG-AT]], 1996 * [[Mikoyan MiG-110|MiG-110]], 1995 * [[Mikoyan Project 1.44|MiG MFI objekt 1.44/1.42]], 1986–2000 * [[Mikoyan Project LFI|MiG LFI project]] * [[Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-105|MiG-105 Spiral]], 1965 * [[Mikoyan MiG-33|MiG-33]] * [[Mikoyan LMFS]]
===UAVs and drones=== *[[MiG Skat]]
=== Naming conventions === MiGs follow the convention of using odd numbers for fighter aircraft. However, this naming convention is maintained not directly by MiG, but by ordering institutions, such as Ministry of Defence or Council of Ministers' Military-Industrial Commission (while in Soviet Union). The original designations for MiG aircraft are 2- or 3-digit numbers, separated by a dot. 1.44 or 1.42 is an example of original naming. Although the MiG-8 and MiG-110 exist, they are not fighters. The MiG-105 "Spiral" was designed as an orbital interceptor, contemporaneous with the U.S. Air Force's cancelled [[X-20 Dyna-Soar]].
